Classifications: The Devil is Tricked into Revealing a Secret
Variation Example: The devil (ogre, giant) maliciously watches a smith trying unsuccessfully to forge iron (plate a vessel with tin). When the smith claims falsely that he has succeeded, the devil asks who told him to use sand (salammoniac). In some variants, a miller learns from the devil to install a vibrat-ing sieve in his mill.

Three main introductions can be distinguished: (1) A man throws his quarrelsome wife into a pit (well, gorge). Later he feels sorry (compassionate) & he wants to get her out. But instead of her, he pulls up a devil (demon) who lives in the pit & cannot endure the evil woman either. (2) A devil marries (wants to marry) a young woman & is tricked by his mother-in-law into a bottle (box). A hunter sets him free. (3) (Belfagor.) Souls in hell complain about bad women on earth. The devil(s) wants to test what it is like to live with a wife. In some variants, a man prefers to endure the torments of hell rather than live with his evil wife. The devil comes to an agreement with him: If the devil cannot live with the man’s wife for a certain time, the man may leave hell. The devil marries (lives with) an evil woman (widow) whom he wants to get rid of quickly. He gets help from a man (farmer, farmhand). The tale is usually continued by an agreement between the grate-ful devil & the man who helped him: A (rich) person (princess) is possessed by the devil. Twice the devil allows the helper to expel him from the possessed person, & the helper is given a big reward. The third time, the devil refuses to leave the possessed per son. The helper threatens the devil with the evil woman (his wife, mother-in-law). The devil flees.

A farmer is on friendly terms with a troll whom he does not want to come to his child’s baptism because he knows the troll’s appetite. Not wishing to offend him, he invites the troll, but says that among the guests there will be the Virgin Mary, Thor the Thunderer, etc. The troll thinks he had better stay away, but he will give the finest present. In a Latvian version, the devil promises the youth the maiden he desires, but he must let the devil spend the first night with her. The devil comes to the wedding, but when he hears that Thunder & Lightning have also been invited, he runs away.

The devil keeps guard in place of a soldier (enlists in military service instead of a youth, who promises him his soul). He cannot endure it that the straps of his knapsack cross each other & is punished.
Misc. type. The devil is frightened by a shoe-maker & gives him gold. He is threatened (beaten) by a soldier, who uses a crucifix or exorcised by a foolhardy man who draws a magic circle, etc.
A man has a mirror in his bag. He tells a demon (tiger) that he has captured other demons & shows him the bag. The demon sees his reflection, mistakes it for another demon, & flees.

Classifications: The Tree Demon Pays the Man to Save the Tree
Variation Example: A man is about to cut down a tree. The demon who lives in the tree promises to bring the man a large amount of rice each month (year) or a treasure of gold if he will desist. When the demon later on gets tired of the bargain, he enters the man’s house (sends another demon) in order to kill him. By chance the man discovers the demon. He threatens to kill him & thus forces him to bring even more rice.

Classifications: The Virgin Mary Saves a Woman sold to the Devil
Variation Example: A man sells his wife to the devil. Before the woman is to be delivered, she goes to church to pray for help to the Virgin Mary. Substituting for the woman , Mary goes to the devil, who flees.

While wandering on earth, Christ & St. Peter (Santa Claus) meet a woman (old man) who is quarreling with the devil (serpent). Christ orders St. Peter to settle the quarrel, so St. Peter strikes off the heads of both the devil & the woman. Christ wants to undo the damage & orders St. Peter to replace the heads, but he unfortunately places them on the wrong bodies.

A man (merchant) comes to an agreement with the devil (ogre): If the man is able to sell all his goods, he is to belong to the devil. If anything is left as unsalable, he is to be free. The man puts an evil old woman in a glass case. Even the devil is convinced that no one wants to buy her. Thus the man goes free. In some variants, the devil loses the contest because he does not succeed in selling three women.
A man saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to catch a rabbit in each of a hundred nets set in high trees.

Classifications: All Stones from the Stream or the Field
Variation Example: A man (woman) saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to gather all the stones from a stream (field); or because the devil is not able to count uncountable things like stars, grass, sands of sea, drops of water, etc.

Classifications: The Devil is to Fulfill Three Wishes
Variation Example: A farmer asks the devil for all the tobacco in the world, all the brandy in the world & finally some more brandy in addition. The devil can fulfill the first two wishes but not the last one.

A man saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to make a rope of sand (chaff). In some variants, a ruler demands a rope of sand (ashes) from one of his subjects (man, woman), who – sometimes helped by good advice – is able to perform the task.

A man saves his soul from the devil by wish ing for something impossible. The man’s wife gives the devil one of her curly hairs & orders him to straighten it (forge it straight). The devil is unable to do this, & the man is free.
A man (woman) saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to: (1) catch (make a knot of) his fart (breath); (2) make knots from drops of spilled brandy; (3) catch a noise.

A poor weaver (servant of a miller) sells his soul to the devil for money. As agreed, after seven years the devil takes the weaver away in a sack. The devil leaves the sack outside when he stops at an inn. A beekeeper sets the weaver free & puts a beehive in the sack. When the devil gets to Hell & opens the sack, the bees fly out & sting him. After this, he does not want any weavers in hell.
A man saves his soul from the devil because the latter is not able to fetch a woman’s grindstone – the woman needs it to sharpen her tongue.

Misc. type. A man (boy) promised to the devil saves himself by pos-ing riddles or setting enigmatic tasks that the devil cannot solve or perform: The man asks the devil whether he will hold onto a hammer or let it fall, etc. He orders the devil to catch frogs & place them on a high tree or to shovel grain with a hayfork without tines. In some variants, the devil must unravel a net in a short time or heal a woman’s “wound” by licking.
The devil is ordered to turn a grindstone until he gets tired.

A man (sailor) saves his soul (himself) from the devil (ogre) because the latter does not accomplish a difficult task. This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The devil is unable to pump the whole sea out of a leaky ship. (2) The devil is unable to hold a ship fast on its anchor chain.
A man (woman, girl) saves his soul (herself) from the devil (ogre) because the latter is not able to catch water in a sieve.

A poor man (farmer, student) is to come into the devil’s power if at the end of a year (after ten years) he does not give back a level bushel of gold in return for a heaped one. The man at once hands back the level bushel & keeps the surplus.

The devil comes to an agreement with a man: He will give the man a copper coin, & whenever it is spent, a similar coin will appear in his pocket again. In return, the man will come into the devil’s power when he is sixty years old. The man buys an expensive property & pays with copper coins, so that all the devils in hell are employed in coining them. When the man threatens to buy another property, the devil terminates the agreement.
A man (woman) saves his soul from the devil because the latter does not succeed in washing black wool (cloth, cattle) white.

This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) The devil creates goats which do so much damage that God finally orders the wolves to kill them. The devil asks for compensation, & God promises to give it when all the oaks have no leaves. When the leaves have fallen, the devil again claims his compensation, but God tells him that there is a big oak in Constantinople which still has its leaves. The devil searches for this tree for months. When he comes back, he sees that all the oaks are in leaf again. Boiling with rage, the devil puts out the goats’ eyes & replaces them with his own eyes. (2) God & the devil argue about the division of power. God wants to rule during the time when the trees are in leaf, the devil at other times. A wren who witnesses this contract makes some of the trees to keep their withered leaves until spring comes, & the devil gives up. (3) The devil helps a man to perform a task (by giving him money). In return, the man is to come into the devil’s power when the last leaf falls from the (oak) tree. It never falls. (The devil angrily slashes the leaves.)

A man has to pay the devil when he harvests his first crop. He plants acorns. In some variants, monks argue with a noble family about a piece of land. The noblemen lose in court, but claim a last sowing & harvest. They plant acorns.
A debt must be repaid to the devil when pigs walk home. But they always run.

The devil & a lawyer (judge, bailiff, inspector, etc.) go for a walk. Three (two) times, they meet various persons: e.g. a butcher who wishes the devil will take a pig away, then a farmer who wishes the same for his horse (ox), then a woman who wishes her child be sent to hell.Each time, the lawyer urges the devil to seize the opportunity, but he refuses because the wish was not in earnest. Finally they meet a poor widow (farmer, farmhand) who curses the lawyer for fraud with such intensity that the devil carries him off to hell.

A man (knight, captain, woman) is helped by the devil & in return cedes him his soul. When the devil comes to get it at the appointed time, the man asks for a delay until a short candle burns out. The devil agrees. Thereupon the man blows out the candle (eats up the candle) & is free.

A man is to belong to the devil after he has finishes a certain task, e.g. putting on two boots, counting to three, hitting the devil three times. He never finishes the task & thus saves himself. In some variants, despite his tricks, the man does not win.

An old woman (man, smith, farmer) bargains with the devil (death, creditor who claims his money). Finally she persuades him to come tomorrow, and, in order to be sure, the devil writes the word “tomorrow” on her door. Each time the devil comes for her, the woman shows him the inscription, & the devil goes away. After some days, the devil erases the inscription & threatens to get the woman the next day. The frightened woman hides first in a barrel full of honey & then in a feather-bed. When the devil comes, he is frightened by the strange creature covered with feathers, & flees. In a Russian version, the devil sets out one day & is tricked by the inscription “come yesterday”. In some variants, the devil comes every day until the gate with the inscription rots. He then claims the soul.
A man promises himself to the devil in ex change for money. To save his soul, he stuffs his clothes with straw & hangs them up. The devil thinks the man has hanged himself & is satisfied.

A master builder is not able to finish a bridge or church (within a fixed time) & asks the devil (ogre) for help. The devil demands in return the first being that crosses the bridge (comes into the church). The mas-ter builder drives an animal (e.g. dog, wolf, cat, rooster, pig, goat) across the bridge (into the church), so the devil is cheated out of his human soul. Because its central element corresponds to Type 1191, the follow-ing version is included here: A king vows to sacrifice the first thing he meets, which turns out to be a miller driving a donkey. When the miller is about to be killed, he pleads that the donkey was in front of him. The donkey is beheaded.

A young woman wants to marry anyone, even if it is the devil. A man (mannikin) appears & agrees to marry her (to help her) but demands that she pays him with the first thing she ties up in the morning. Instead of her clothes she ties up (on someone’s advice) a sheaf.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Death (angel of death, devil) goes to take a man who begs for a delay long enough to offer a last prayer. The man does not finish the prayer, so death cannot take him. After a while, death causes the man to finish his prayer (having grown very old, the man decides to finish the prayer & die). (2) Death (devil) cannot take a man (woman) as long as he (she) sings a hymn or a song that never ends.

A woman (women, man) can save herself from the devil (demon, dead persons, bear) by describing in detail how bread (flax) is prepared (what it suffers during preparation). When finally a rooster crows (the sun rises), the devil has to disappear (is transformed into a trunk or stone). In some variants, the bread (flax) itself tells about its sufferings & urges the devil to endure the same. The devil flees.

Fools (numskulls) sow salt in a field & expect it to grow so they can sell the crop for a high price. Instead of salt, nettles grow, & the numskulls are proud of how well the “salt” is doing. In some variants, instead of salt, various substances like cooked grain, needles, gold dust, a small coin, chopped bacon or a hog are sowed or planted.

Classifications: Sowing the Seed in One Place
Variation Example: Numskull(s) sow(s) all the seeds in one furrow.

Four men (numskulls) carry the plow horse so it will not trample down the (sprouting) seeds. In some variants, they carry the man who guards the field on horseback (on a cart, boat, rack, ladder) when he wants to scare away an animal (e.g. stork, cow, pig, horse), so that he will not trample down the growing seeds.
